Part Three, Chapter Thirty-Eight, Section Three of the Chapter on Departing from the World
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas give rise to ten kinds of unsurpassed minds.
What are the ten?
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas think like this:
'I will subdue all celestial demons and their retinues.'
This is the first unsurpassed mind.
They also think like this:
'I will completely destroy all non-Buddhist paths and their false teachings.'
This is the second unsurpassed mind.
They also think like this:
'I will speak kind words to all sentient beings and make them all rejoice.'
This is the third unsurpassed mind.
They also think like this:
'I will fulfill the pÄramitÄs that pervade the Dharma realm.'
This is the fourth fearless mind.
Moreover, one should think like this:
'I will accumulate all merits and virtues.'
This is the fifth fearless mind.
Moreover, one should think like this:
'Unsurpassed enlightenment is vast and difficult to attain, I will cultivate and practice to fulfill it all.'
This is the sixth fearless mind.
Moreover, one should think like this:
'With unsurpassed teaching and unsurpassed discipline, I will teach and discipline all sentient beings.'
This is the seventh fearless mind.
Moreover, one should think like this:
'All worlds are of various kinds, I will manifest perfect enlightenment with immeasurable bodies.'
This is the eighth fearless mind.
Moreover, one should think like this:

'When I cultivate bodhisattva practices, if sentient beings come to beg me for hands, feet, ears, nose, blood, flesh, bones, marrow, wife, children, elephants, horses, up to the position of king, I am able to give away all of these without giving rise to a single thought of worry or regret. I only benefit all sentient beings, not seeking any rewards, with great compassion at the forefront and great kindness as the ultimate.'
This is the ninth unsurpassed mind.
He also thinks like this:

'The buddhas of the three times, all buddha-dharmas, all sentient beings, all lands, all worlds, all three times, all space elements, all dharma elements, all realms of linguistic expression, and all realms of quiescent nirvana - I shall, with a single thought of wisdom, know all of these, awaken to all of them, see all of them, realize all of them, cultivate all of them, and cut off all of them. Yet within them there is no discrimination, no separation from discrimination, no variety, no distinction, no merit, no realm, no existence, no non-existence, no singularity, and no duality.
With non-dual wisdom, one knows all dualities. With signless wisdom, one knows all signs. With
non-discriminating wisdom, one knows all discriminations. With non-differentiating wisdom, one knows all differences. With
non-distinguishing wisdom, one knows all distinctions. With non-worldly wisdom, one knows all worlds.
With the wisdom of non-worldly affairs, they know all worldly affairs; with the wisdom of non-sentient beings, they know all sentient beings;
With the wisdom of non-attachment, they know all attachments; with the wisdom of no dwelling place, they know all dwelling places;
With the wisdom of non-defilement, they know all defilements; with the wisdom of non-extinction, they know all extinctions;

With the wisdom of the ultimate Dharma realm, they manifest bodies in all worlds; with the wisdom of transcending verbal sounds, they demonstrate inexpressible sounds; with the wisdom of a single nature, they enter into the natureless;
With the wisdom of a single realm, they manifest various realms.
They know that all dharmas are inexpressible, yet they manifest great mastery in speech and realize the stage of omniscience;
In order to teach and tame all sentient beings, they demonstrate great spiritual transformations in all worlds.
This is the tenth unsurpassed mind.
Buddha's disciples!
These are the ten unsurpassed minds that the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should give rise to.
If bodhisattvas abide in this mind, they will attain all the supreme and unsurpassed buddha-dharmas.
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have ten kinds of mountain-like superior minds towards anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
What are the ten?
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas always diligently cultivate the dharmas of omniscience, this is the first mountain-like superior mind.
Constantly contemplating that all dharmas are originally empty and without attainment, this is the second mountain-like superior mind.

Vowing to practice the bodhisattva path for immeasurable eons, cultivating all pure dharmas, and because of abiding in all pure dharmas, knowing and seeing the immeasurable wisdom of the TathÄgata, this is the third mountain-like superior mind.

In order to seek all Buddha-Dharmas, they respectfully serve all good and wise advisors with an impartial mind, without any other desires or thoughts of stealing the Dharma. They only give rise to respect and have never had any other thoughts. They are able to give up everything they have. This is the fourth mountain-like superior resolve.

If there are sentient beings who scold, slander, beat, strike, cut, or even take their lives, they are able to endure all such things and will never become agitated or give rise to thoughts of anger or harm because of this. They will also not regress or abandon their great compassion and vast vows, but will cause them to increase without rest.
Why is this?
Because bodhisattvas truly renounce and accomplish all dharmas,
and have already mastered the patience and gentleness of realizing all the Dharmas of the TathÄgatas.
This is the fifth mountain-like superior resolve.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas accomplish the superior great merits, namely:

the supreme merit of devas, the supreme merit of humans, the supreme merit of form, the supreme merit of strength, the supreme merit of retinue, the supreme merit of desire, the supreme merit of kingship, the supreme merit of sovereignty, the supreme merit of blessings and virtues, and the supreme merit of wisdom.
Although they have accomplished such merits, they are never attached to them, namely:
not attached to flavors, not attached to desires, not attached to wealth, and not attached to retinue;

but deeply delighting in the Dharma, following the Dharma, abiding in the Dharma, heading towards the Dharma, and ultimately reaching the Dharma, taking the Dharma as their reliance, taking the Dharma as their refuge, taking the Dharma as their return, and taking the Dharma as their home, guarding the Dharma, delighting in the Dharma, aspiring for the Dharma, and contemplating the Dharma.
Buddha's disciple!
Although the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva is fully endowed with various kinds of enjoyment of the Dharma, he always stays far away from the realms of the mÄras.
Why is it so?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas give rise to this mind in the past:
'I shall cause all sentient beings to forever leave the realm of mÄras and abide in the realm of the Buddha.'
This is the sixth mind like a mountain.

For the sake of seeking anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have already practiced the bodhisattva path for immeasurable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas, diligently and tirelessly, yet they still think:
'I am now just beginning to give rise to the mind of anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.'
While practicing the bodhisattva path, they are neither startled, nor frightened, nor afraid.

Although they can attain anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi in a single thought, for the sake of sentient beings, they practice the bodhisattva path for immeasurable kalpas without rest. This is the seventh mind like a mountain.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know that the nature of all sentient beings is unruly, difficult to tame, difficult to save, unable to know gratitude, and unable to repay kindness. Therefore, they give rise to great vows for them, wishing to enable them all to attain mastery of mind and intention, to be unobstructed in their actions, to abandon evil thoughts, and not to give rise to afflictions towards others. This is the eighth mountain-like superior resolve.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas further think like this:
It is not others who cause me to give rise to the resolve for enlightenment, nor do I depend on others to assist me in practicing.
I myself give rise to the resolve, gather the Buddha's teachings, vow to strive on my own, and in the future kalpas practice the bodhisattva path to attain supreme perfect enlightenment.

Therefore, when I now cultivate bodhisattva practices, I should purify my own mind and also purify others' minds, I should know my own realm and also know others' realms, and I should be equal to the realms of all Buddhas of the three times.
This is the ninth mountain-like superior resolve.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas contemplate in this way:

'There is not a single dharma that cultivates the bodhisattva practice, there is not a single dharma that fulfills the bodhisattva practice, there is not a single dharma that teaches and tames all sentient beings, there is not a single dharma that makes offerings and respects all buddhas, there is not a single dharma that has already, is now, or will attain supreme perfect enlightenment, there is not a single dharma that has already been taught, is now being taught, or will be taught, and the teacher and the dharma are both unobtainable, yet one does not abandon the vow for supreme perfect enlightenment.
' Why is it so?
Bodhisattvas seek all dharmas and find nothing. In this way, supreme perfect enlightenment arises.

Therefore, although there is nothing to attain in the Dharma, one diligently cultivates superior wholesome karma, purifies counteragents, perfects wisdom, and increases all endowments moment by moment.
Their minds are not startled or frightened by this, and they do not think:
'If all dharmas are completely extinguished, what meaning do I have in seeking the path of unsurpassed bodhi?'
This is the tenth mountain-like superior resolve.
Buddha's disciple!
These are the ten mountain-like superior resolves of the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva regarding unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment.
If bodhisattvas abide in them, they will attain the unsurpassed great wisdom mountain king's superior resolve of the TathÄgata.
Buddha's disciple!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva has ten kinds of entry into unsurpassed, perfect enlightenment that are like the wisdom of the ocean.
What are the ten?
They are:ğŸ”½Entering all immeasurable realms of sentient beings is the first wisdom that is like the ocean.
Entering all worlds without giving rise to discrimination is the second wisdom that is like the ocean.
Knowing that the immeasurable and unobstructed realm of space universally enters the net of all differentiated worlds in the ten directions is the third knowledge like the ocean.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas skillfully enter the Dharma realm, namely:

Unimpeded entry, non-annihilation entry, non-eternity entry, immeasurable entry, non-arising entry, non-cessation entry, and all-inclusive entry, because they fully understand them, this is the fourth knowledge like the ocean.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know all the wholesome roots gathered by the Buddhas, Bodhisattvas, Dharma teachers, ÅšrÄvakas, Pratyekabuddhas, and all ordinary beings of the past, future, and present, the wholesome roots possessed by the Buddhas of the three times who have already attained, are now attaining, or will attain supreme perfect enlightenment, the wholesome roots possessed by the Buddhas of the three times who have already taught, are now teaching, or will teach the Dharma to tame all beings, and they know all of this. With deep faith and joy, they aspire to cultivate and practice without ever being satisfied. This is the fifth ocean-like wisdom.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, in each and every thought, enter into the past world's inexpressible eons, in one eon, either a hundred koá¹­Ä«s of Buddhas appearing in the world, or a thousand koá¹­Ä«s of Buddhas appearing in the world, or a hundred thousand koá¹­Ä«s of Buddhas appearing in the world, or innumerable, or immeasurable, or boundless, or unequaled, or incalculable, or uncountable, or inconceivable, or unfathomable, or inexpressible, or inexpressibly inexpressible, surpassing the number of Buddhas, World-Honored Ones, who appear in the world, and the assemblies at their sites of enlightenment, the Å›rÄvakas, bodhisattvas, the Dharma they expound and tame, all beings' lifespans, long or short, the Dharma abiding for a long or short time, all of this they clearly see;
as with one eon, so it is with all eons.
In the eons without Buddhas, all beings who plant various roots of goodness for anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, they also fully understand;
If there are sentient beings whose wholesome roots have matured, they will be able to see the Buddha in the future, and [the bodhisattva] also fully understands this.
Thus observing the past for inexpressibly inexpressible eons, [the bodhisattva's] mind is never satisfied. This is the sixth knowledge like the ocean.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas enter the future and observe and discern all eons as being immeasurable and boundless, knowing in which eons there are buddhas and in which eons there are no buddhas, how many tathÄgatas appear in each eon, what the names of each tathÄgata are, in which worlds they reside, what the names of those worlds are, how many sentient beings they liberate, and how long their lifespans are.
Thus observing to the end of the future, [the bodhisattva] fully understands and knows everything, never becoming exhausted or dissatisfied. This is the seventh knowledge like the ocean.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas enter the present world and observe and contemplate, seeing in every moment of thought the boundless categories of worlds in the ten directions, all of which have buddhas who have already attained, are now attaining, and will attain supreme enlightenment, going to the site of enlightenment, under the bodhi tree, sitting on auspicious grass, subduing the demon armies, and accomplishing supreme perfect enlightenment;

rising from there, entering cities and towns, ascending to heavenly palaces, expounding the subtle Dharma, turning the great Dharma wheel, manifesting spiritual powers, taming sentient beings, and finally entrusting the Dharma of supreme perfect enlightenment, abandoning their lifespans, and entering parinirvÄá¹‡a;
after entering parinirvÄá¹‡a, compiling the Dharma treasury to abide in the world for a long time, adorning the Buddha's stÅ«pas, and making various offerings.

They also see the sentient beings in those worlds encountering the Buddha, hearing the Dharma, upholding and reciting it, recollecting and contemplating it, and increasing their wisdom and understanding.
Thus observing universally in the ten directions, yet without error in the Buddha's teachings.
Why is it so?
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas understand that all buddhas are like dreams, yet they are able to go to all the buddhas' places and respectfully make offerings.

At that time, the bodhisattva is not attached to his own body, not attached to the buddhas, not attached to the worlds, not attached to the assemblies, not attached to the teachings, and not attached to the eons. Yet he sees the buddhas, hears the teachings, observes the worlds, enters the eons, and is never satisfied. This is the eighth ocean-like wisdom.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, in each of the ineffably ineffable eons, make offerings and respectfully serve ineffably ineffable incalculable buddhas, manifesting their own bodies passing away here and being born there, using all offerings that transcend the three realms to make offerings, as well as making offerings to the bodhisattvas, Å›rÄvakas, and the great assemblies;
After each TathÄgata's parinirvÄá¹‡a, they all made offerings to the relics with the unsurpassed offerings and extensively practiced giving to fulfill the needs of sentient beings.
Buddha's disciple!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, with an inconceivable mind, a mind not seeking recompense, a mind of ultimate completion, and a mind of benefit, for incalculably long eons, for the sake of supreme perfect enlightenment, make offerings to the buddhas, benefit sentient beings, uphold the true Dharma, and reveal and expound it. This is the ninth knowledge like the ocean.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, in the presence of all buddhas, all bodhisattvas, and all Dharma teachers, single-mindedly seek the Dharma taught by bodhisattvas, the Dharma learned by bodhisattvas, the Dharma taught by bodhisattvas, the Dharma practiced by bodhisattvas, the pure Dharma of bodhisattvas, the Dharma of maturing bodhisattvas, the Dharma of taming bodhisattvas, the equal Dharma of bodhisattvas, the Dharma of liberation for bodhisattvas, and the Dharma of upholding for bodhisattvas;
Having attained this Dharma, they uphold, recite, and explain it without ever tiring of it;

causing countless sentient beings to give rise to the mind of omniscience in accord with the Buddha's teachings, to enter the true characteristics, and to attain irreversibility in anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
The bodhisattvas are like this, never tiring even in ineffably ineffable eons. This is the tenth ocean-like wisdom.
Buddha's disciples!
These are the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva's ten kinds of ocean-like wisdoms for entering anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
If the bodhisattvas abide in these principles, they will attain the great wisdom ocean of all buddhas, which is unsurpassed.
Buddha's disciples!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva has ten kinds of dwelling like a treasure in anuttarÄ-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi.
What are the ten?
Buddha's disciples!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are all able to go to the places of the tathÄgatas in countless worlds, to look up to them, bow to them, serve them, and make offerings to them. This is the first like-jewel abode.

In the inconceivable places of the tathÄgatas, they listen to the true Dharma, uphold and remember it, not letting it be forgotten, and discern and contemplate it, causing their wisdom to increase. Their deeds like this fill the ten directions. This is the second like-jewel abode.
Here they die and are reborn elsewhere, but they are not confused about the Buddha's teachings. This is the third like-jewel abode.

Knowing that all dharmas arise from one dharma, yet being able to explain them individually, because the various meanings of all dharmas ultimately are just one meaning. This is the fourth like-jewel abode.

Knowing to be disgusted with and leave afflictions, knowing to stop and rest afflictions, knowing to guard against afflictions, knowing to eliminate and cut off afflictions, cultivating bodhisattva practices without realizing the ultimate truth, ultimately reaching the other shore of the ultimate truth, skillful in means, well-trained in learning, causing past vows and practices to all be fulfilled, the body not weary, this is the fifth like-jewel abode.
Knowing that all the mental discriminations of sentient beings are all without location, yet also speaking of various locations;
Although without discrimination and without fabrication, in order to subdue all sentient beings there is practice and there is action, this is the sixth like-jewel abode.
Knowing that all dharmas are of the same nature, namely:

It has no nature, no various natures, no immeasurable natures, no countable natures, no measurable natures, no form, no characteristics, whether one or many, all cannot be obtained. Yet it definitely knows that this is the Dharma of all Buddhas, this is the Dharma of Bodhisattvas, this is the Dharma of Pratyekabuddhas, this is the Dharma of Sravakas, this is the Dharma of ordinary beings, this is good Dharma, this is bad Dharma, this is worldly Dharma, this is supramundane Dharma, this is Dharma with faults, this is Dharma without faults, this is Dharma with outflows, this is Dharma without outflows, up to this is conditioned Dharma, this is unconditioned Dharma. This is the seventh like-jewel abode.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas seek the Buddha but cannot attain it, seek the bodhisattva but cannot attain it, seek the Dharma but cannot attain it, seek sentient beings but cannot attain them, yet they do not abandon the vow to tame sentient beings and realize perfect enlightenment in all dharmas.
Why is it so?

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas skillfully contemplate and understand all sentient beings' discriminations, understand all sentient beings' realms, and skillfully guide and transform them to attain nirvÄá¹‡a;
In order to fulfill the vow to transform sentient beings and to diligently cultivate bodhisattva practices.
This is the eighth like-a-treasure abode.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know the skillful means of teaching the Dharma and manifesting nirvÄá¹‡a in order to liberate sentient beings, all of which are established by the mind, not inverted, and not false.
Why is it so?

Bodhisattvas understand that all dharmas are equal in the three times, suchness is unmoving, and the ultimate reality is without abiding. They do not see a single sentient being who has already been transformed, is being transformed, or will be transformed. They also understand that there is no cultivation of practice and that there is not a single dharma that can be attained, whether arising or ceasing. Yet, they rely on all dharmas to make their vows not empty.
This is the ninth like-a-treasure abode.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas hear the inconceivable and immeasurable buddhas, each one's innumerable predictions of the Dharma, with different names and different eons,

from one eon up to innumerable eons, constantly hearing in this way. Having heard, they practice without alarm, without fear, without confusion, because they know the inconceivable wisdom of the TathÄgata, because the TathÄgata's words of prediction are non-dual, because the power of their own practice and vows is supreme, and because they cause those to be transformed as appropriate to perfect unsurpassed perfect enlightenment and fulfill all vows equal to the Dharma realm. This is the tenth, like a treasure abode.
Buddha's disciple!
These are the bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas' ten kinds of abodes like treasures in unsurpassed perfect enlightenment.
If bodhisattvas abide in these dharmas, they will attain the unsurpassed great wisdom treasure of the buddhas.
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas give rise to ten kinds of adamantine great vehicle vow minds.
What are the ten?
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas think like this:
'All dharmas are boundless and inexhaustible.
I shall awaken to them all without exception using the wisdom that exhausts the three times.'
This is the first adamantine great vehicle vow mind.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas also think like this:
'There are innumerable and boundless sentient beings in the space of a single hair, let alone the entire Dharma realm!
I shall deliver them all to the unsurpassed nirvÄá¹‡a.'

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas also think like this:
'The worlds in the ten directions are immeasurable, boundless, limitless, and inexhaustible.
I shall adorn all these worlds with the supreme adornments of the Buddha-lands, and all the adornments shall be completely real.'
This is the third adamantine vow of the Great Vehicle.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas further think like this:
'All sentient beings are immeasurable, boundless, limitless, and inexhaustible.
I shall use all wholesome roots to dedicate them to that unsurpassed wisdom-light, illuminating them.'
This is the fourth adamantine vow of the Great Vehicle.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas further think like this:
'All Buddhas are immeasurable, boundless, limitless, and inexhaustible.
I shall use the wholesome roots I have planted to make offerings to them, ensuring that they are all-pervasive and lacking nothing, and only then shall I attain supreme perfect enlightenment.'
This is the fifth adamantine great vehicle vow mind.
Buddha's disciple!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas see all buddhas, hear the Dharma they teach, and give rise to great joy. They are not attached to their own bodies or to the buddhas' bodies. They understand that the TathÄgata's body is neither real nor false, neither existent nor nonexistent, neither with nature nor without nature, neither form nor formless, neither with characteristics nor without characteristics, neither born nor extinguished. It is truly nonexistent, yet it is also not destroyed.
Why is this?
Because one cannot grasp it with any nature or characteristics.
This is the sixth adamantine great vehicle vow mind.
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, whether sentient beings scold, insult, beat, strike, cut off their hands and feet, cut off their ears and nose, gouge out their eyes, or behead them;
in all such cases they are able to endure it and never give rise to an angry or harmful mind because of it.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
For countless, inexpressible, inexpressibly vast eons, they cultivate bodhisattva practices and always tirelessly accept and embrace sentient beings.
Why is this?

Because bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have already well observed that all dharmas are without two characteristics, their minds are unmoved and unconfused, and they are able to endure the suffering of giving up their own bodies.
This is the seventh mind of great vehicle vows like vajra.
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas further think like this:
'Future world eons are immeasurable, boundless, limitless, and inexhaustible.
I shall exhaust those eons, in one world, practicing the bodhisattva path and teaching and transforming sentient beings;
Just as in one world, throughout the entire dharma realm, the realm of space, and all worlds, it shall be the same, yet my mind will not be startled, frightened, or fearful.
Why is this?
Because it is the dharma of the bodhisattva path to practice like this for the sake of all sentient beings.'
This is the eighth adamantine great vehicle vow mind.
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattva should also think like this:

Anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi takes the mind as its basis. If the mind is pure, then it can fully perfect all wholesome roots. In the Buddha's enlightenment, one will certainly attain mastery. If one wishes to accomplish anuttara-samyak-saá¹ƒbodhi, it can be accomplished as one wishes.

If one wishes to eliminate all grasping and abide in the one-sided path, I can also attain it, but I do not end it. It is in order to ultimately attain the Buddha's enlightenment. I do not immediately realize supreme enlightenment.
Why is it so?
It is in order to fulfill my original vow, to exhaust all worlds, to practice the bodhisattva path, and to transform sentient beings.
This is the ninth adamantine great vehicle vow mind.
Buddha's disciple!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas know that the Buddha cannot be attained, enlightenment cannot be attained, bodhisattvas cannot be attained, all dharmas cannot be attained, sentient beings cannot be attained, the mind cannot be attained, practice cannot be attained, the past cannot be attained, the future cannot be attained, the present cannot be attained, all worlds cannot be attained, and the conditioned and unconditioned cannot be attained.

In this way, the bodhisattva abides in tranquility, abides in the profound, abides in quiescence, abides without conflict, abides without duality, abides without equality, abides in self-nature, abides in suchness, abides in liberation, abides in nirvÄá¹‡a, and abides in reality, yet he does not abandon all great vows, does not abandon the mind of omniscience, does not abandon bodhisattva practices, does not abandon teaching and transforming sentient beings, does not abandon the perfections, does not abandon subduing sentient beings, does not abandon serving the buddhas, does not abandon expounding the dharmas, and does not abandon adorning the worlds.
Why is it so?

Because the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva has made great vows. Although he has thoroughly understood all the characteristics of dharmas, his mind of great compassion grows even greater, and he practices the cultivation of immeasurable merit without abandoning the mind of great compassion for any sentient being.
Why is it so?
All dharmas are non-existent. Foolish ordinary beings do not know or understand. I should cause them to attain great enlightenment and clearly illuminate the nature of all dharmas.
Why is it so?
All buddhas abide in quiescence, yet with a mind of great compassion, they expound the Dharma and teach and transform the world without ever resting.
How can I now abandon great compassion?

Moreover, I have previously given rise to a mind of vast and great vows, a mind of definite benefit to all sentient beings, a mind of accumulating all wholesome roots, a mind of skillfully abiding in skillful dedication, a mind of giving rise to profound wisdom, a mind of embracing all sentient beings, and a mind of equality towards all sentient beings.
I speak true words and not deceptive words, vowing to bestow the unsurpassed great Dharma to all sentient beings, vowing not to cut off the lineage of all Buddhas.

Now, all sentient beings have not yet attained liberation, have not yet realized perfect enlightenment, have not yet perfected the Buddha's teachings, and their great vows have not yet been fulfilled. How can I wish to abandon great compassion?
This is the tenth mind of great vehicle vows as firm as vajra.
Buddha's disciples!
These are the ten minds of great vehicle vows as firm as vajra that the bodhisattva-mahÄsattva gives rise to.
If bodhisattvas abide in these dharmas, they will attain the vajra nature of the TathÄgata's unsurpassed great supernatural powers and wisdom. Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have ten kinds of great aspirations.
What are the ten?
Buddha's disciple!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas have this thought:
'I will make offerings and pay homage to all buddhas.'
This is the first great aspiration.
They also have this thought:
'I will nurture all bodhisattvas' wholesome roots.'
This is the second great aspiration.
They also have this thought:

'After all tathÄgatas have entered parinirvÄá¹‡a, I will adorn stÅ«pas of the buddhas and make offerings with all flowers, all garlands, all incense, all ointments, all powdered incense, all clothing, all canopies, all banners, and all flags, and uphold and protect their true Dharma.'
This is the third great inspiration.
He also thinks like this:
'I should teach and tame all sentient beings, enabling them to attain supreme, perfect enlightenment.'
This is the fourth great inspiration.
He also thinks like this:
'I should adorn all worlds with the unsurpassed adornments of the Buddha-lands.'
This is the fifth great inspiration.
